awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: INFEWS N/P/H2O: Supramolecular Recognition in the Biocatalytic Transformation of Organic Phosphorus-Containing Environmental Matrices
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences program in the Division of Chemistry. It supports Dr. Ludmilla Aristilde of Cornell University and Dr. Deb Jaisi of the University of Delaware to investigate the cycling of phosphorus in the environment. Phosphorus (P) is an essential component of fertilizers, but in excess, a pollutant. Inorganic phosphorus is the form required by plants. Animals can use either organic or inorganic phosphorus. Both organic and inorganic phosphorus can be dissolved or suspended in water.  The transformation of organic P to inorganic P is poorly understood. The key research objective is to better understand the chemical controls of this transformation. Outreach activities are carried out on the topic of the fate of organic P including fertilizers, organic wastes, and organic matter in soils. The outreach is aimed at increasing public literacy, from inner-city middle school students to farmers. Both investigators are involved in educational activities for farmers in New York and Delaware, respectively. Different stakeholders gain valuable knowledge regarding nutrient and fertilizer management on agricultural lands.

This project applies a multidisciplinary approach. The research activities combine tools from molecular biology, analytical chemistry, and computational modeling. Molecular-level insights are obtained on the chemical factors that control the enzymatic release of inorganic P from complex organic assemblages. The project has three main objectives. First, it studies the activities of phosphatase enzymes with organic assemblages. Second, it addresses the effects of mineral surfaces on enzyme-substrate recognition. Third, the catalytic dynamics in response to external chemical stimuli is modeled. Metabolomics profiling enables the monitoring of catalytic hydrolysis of different organic P assemblages. Isotopes are used to track enzyme catalysis. This provides information on the role of different enzymes in recycling organic P in response to the chemistry of the environmental matrix. Molecular dynamics simulations in concert with the experimental studies illustrate the supramolecular framework responsible for the environmental biotransformation of organic P. The research findings shed light on how biogeochemical factors control phosphatase-mediated inorganic P generation from organic P assemblages. This addresses a long-standing knowledge gap in the environmental mapping of P species and their fate in soils and waters.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food-Energy-

por.por_cntn:
The major objective of this research was to characterize, quantify, and model the catalytic roles of multiple phosphatase enzymes on substrate (organic phosphorus) recognition and transformation. This project supported collaborative research between Northwestern University and the University of Delaware and mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral associates in the project.

 The UD portion of the collaborative research generated seven peer-reviewed publications. Five were research papers (Hu et al., 2020; Bai et al., 2020; Sun et al., 2021; Campos et al., 2021; Moller et al., 2022), one review paper (Jaisi et al., 2022), and one manuscript (Solhtalab et al., 2022) currently under revision. It further yielded 17 presentations at conferences and professional society meetings. Among them, one was the keynote talk, six invited talks, and ten were presentations. Among these outcomes, two papers and three presentations were made collaboratively with Northwestern University.

 This research generated a series of significant scientific findings. The major ones are metal complexation caused by enzymatic inhibition, adsorption and precipitation of organic phosphorus on mineral surfaces, and isotopologue and isotope signatures during enzymatic reactions with organic phosphorus compounds. These findings have the following implications: i) Complexation-based research outcomes contribute to the current understanding of the fate of phytate in the presence of various metals that are commonly present in agricultural soils. ii) Specific isotopes and fractionation factors during synthesis and hydrolysis of polyphosphate could serve as proxies to interpret polyphosphate dynamics in the environment and contribute to the target goal of reducing phosphorus in wastewater treatment plants; iii) Isotopologue formed during enzyme-substrate reaction provided a proxy that could be used for the interpretation of oxygen isotope variations for phosphate in both natural and engineered environments.

 The UD portion of the project supported training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral associate for their education, enhancing their technical skills, and achieving higher success in their careers. One graduate student completed the thesis and the other is ready to graduate coming summer. The postdoctoral associate is now an assistant professor at a US university.

 Data generated from this project contributed partly to achieving the major research instrument award from the USDA NIFA program. This project partially aided in establishing a new isotope facility, the Environmental Isotope Science (EIS) Center, at the University of Delaware. This center has served as a training venue for graduate students and postdoctoral associates including through the ‘isotope scholar’ program. The state-of-the-art isotope facility continues to serve the research needs of diverse researchers and connect communities of scientists for environmental isotope areas at UD and the region.

Other collaborations initiated from this project with US and foreign scientists on various aspects of the separation and identification of organic phosphorus compounds and quantifying reactions in different environmental matrices, isotope data analysis, and refining synthesis of isotope-labeled organic compounds are active. These collaborations will continue in future years.


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: Deb P Jaisi
